variant.question: An aircraft is flying on coastal line. After an engine failure at 10 000 ft. What will be the expected gliding distance of the aircraft if the L/D ratio is 9:1?

options.text: increased or decreased depending upon the type of flap.

variant.question:
An aeroplane is in a power off glide at speed for minimum glide angle
If the pilot increases pitch attitude the glide distance

options.text: may increase or decrease depending on the type of aeroplane.

in flight, its VMD will ....(1).... and if it maintained the clean

options.text: parasite drag is equal to the induced drag.
parasite drag equals twice the induced drag.
induced drag is equal to zero.

variant.question: An aircraft in straight and level flight maintains a constant IAS. What else is constant?

options.text: It is at maximum throughout the range

If the centre of gravity is near the forward limit, the aeroplane will

options.text: require elevator trim, which will result in an increase in fuel consumption.
benefit from reduced drag due to the decrease in angle of attack.
tend to over rotate during take-off.
require less power for a given airspeed.

variant.question: In the transonic speed region the L/D ratio is..
If descending with a constant TAS, what happens?
An aeroplane is flying in steady, straight and level flight at its 1g stall speed. If the pilot intends to turn left using the ailerons, the aeroplane will...

options.text: bank to the right, because the down going aileron will exceed the critical angle of attack.
maintain straight and level flight because the ailerons will be unresponsive due to flow separation.
Yaw to the left, because of increased drag due to flow separation on the downgoing aileron.
bank to the left provided the speed does NOT decrease below the stalling speed.

variant.question:
The value of the manoeuvre stability of an aeroplane is 125 N/g
The stick force required to achieve a load factor of 4 from steady straight and level trimmed flight is

A light aeroplane is in steady, straight and level fight at a low subsonic speed, with no flaps. On reaching a turning point the pilot at a constant speed, uses a load factor of 1.15 to maintain level flight. Due to the turn, the coefficient of lift:
When the stick force required to achieve a load factor of 2.5 from steady straight and level trimmed flight is 225 N, the value of the manoeuvre stability of that aeroplane is
When the stick force required to achieve a load factor of 2.5 from steady straight and level trimmed flight is 375 N, the value of the manoeuvre stability of that aeroplane is
When the stick force required to achieve a load factor of 2.5 from steady straight and level trimmed flight is 150 N, the value of the manoeuvre stability of that aeroplane is

You are the pilot flying of a commercial jet aircraft and just started your descent by using the autopilot, which controls the speed with pitch control. Passing FL340, the aeroplane passes through a jet stream and experiences a sudden positive wind shear. The speed increases momentarily to M0.85 causing the autopilot to demand a pitch up to arrest the speed increase. Since M0.85 is approximately 5 kt faster than M~MO~, you may...

options.text: feel a slight vibration as a result of the increased positive load factor creating some buffet, due to shock waves during the overspeed.
feel significant buffeting from the shock waves, which from at speeds above MMO, further enhanced by the increased load factor.
experience momentary loss of control due to incipient shock stall until the aeroplane recovers and speed reduces below M~MO~.
experience a slight “Mach tuck” effect as shock waves increase in strength, leading to further speed increase and loss of speed control.

When an aeroplane with the centre of gravity forward of the centre of pressure of the combined wing / fuselage is in straight and level flight, the vertical load on the tailplane will be

options.text: zero because in steady flight all loads are in equilibrium.
downwards because it is always negative regardless of the position of the centre of gravity.

variant.question: In straight flight, as speed is reduced, whilst trimming to keep the stick force zero:

options.text: the elevator is deflected further upwards and the trim tab further downwards.
the elevator and trim tab do not move.
both elevator and trim tab are deflected further upwards.
the elevator is deflected further downwards and the trim tab further upwards.

variant.question: In straight flight, as speed is increased, whilst trimming to keep the stick force zero:

options.text: the elevator is deflected further downwards and the trim tab further upwards.
the elevator is deflected further upwards and the trim tab further downwards.
both elevator and trim tab are deflected further downwards.
the elevator and trim tab do not move.

variant.question: To side slip an aircraft to the right, the pilot would apply:
For an aeroplane with one fixed value of V~A~ the following applies. V~A~ is:

options.text: the speed at which the aeroplane stalls at the manoeuvring limit load factor at MTOW.
the speed at which unrestricted application of full control surface deflection can be made, without exceeding the maximum manoeuvring limit load factor.
the maximum speed in smooth air.
just another symbol for the rough air speed.

variant.question: All other parameters remaining constant, what happens to V~A~ (Design Manoeuvring Speed) if the weight of an aeroplane reduces by 20%?

options.text: i) can be greater than or less than ii) depending on the type of aeroplane

variant.question: If the density altitude increases, what happens to the Minimum Control Speed (VMC)?

You are flying from town A to airport B with a single engine piston when you experience an engine failure. Calculate the minimum altitude at A to reach to airport B, given:
Elevation: 300 mDistance from A to B: 60 kmL/D ratio: 30
Why would a pilot choose to glide for minimum rate of descent after complete engine failure?

options.text: To give the maximum time to complete emergency drills before a forced landing or ditching.
To glide as far as possible in a headwind.
To give maximum airflow through jet engines, to assist a restart.
To give the best chance of reaching a suitable forced landing aerodrome.

variant.question: A twin engine turbojet large transport aircraft has lost both engines while flying close to the Azores. What is the maximum glide distance from an altitude of 10 km if the lift/drag ration is 12:1?

You are planning an IFR flight and have to comply with published speeds for your aircraft category at the arrival aerodrome. What can happen if the aircraft is faster than the published speed upon arrival?

options.text: The aircraft may fly outside the limits of the safe zone due to its turn radius.
The aircraft may be bank angle or stall speed limited.
The aircraft may be rate of turn or stall speed limited.
The aircraft may fly outside the limits of the safe zone and be roll rate limited.

variant.question: What is correct regarding minimum glide angle?

options.text: It's the best distance to change in height ratio
It's the best time to change in height ratio
It's the best time to fuel ratio
It's the best distance to fuel ratio

VMCG remains constant for the same configuration.
VMCG decreases due to the increasing density.
VMCG increases due to decreasing rudder effectiveness.

should:

1.  V~MCL~
 is the minimum control speed in the landing configuration.

options.text: Outside limit of safe zone/roll rate.

variant.question: The maximum ground distance during a glide with zero thrust decreases:

options.text: in a headwind at a constant aeroplane mass compared with zero wind.
with a decrease in aeroplane mass in zero wind.
in a tailwind with constant aeroplane mass compared with zero wind.
with an increase in aeroplane mass in zero wind.

variant.question: The maximum ground distance during a glide with zero thrust increases:

options.text: in a tailwind at a constant aeroplane mass compared with zero wind.
with a decrease in aeroplane mass in zero wind.
with an increase in aeroplane mass in zero wind.
in a headwind at a constant aeroplane mass compared with zero wind.

variant.question: The maximum glide range of an aircraft will depend on wind and:

options.text: the ratio to lift to drag which varies according to angle of attack.
